seed_message:
You're starting intention-setting work with someone.

Intentions work like a compass - they point toward what matters without forcing the destination.

I'll help you build 3 intentions.

What brought you to this work?
system0:
Let's set intentions.

Intentions work like a compass - they point toward what matters without forcing the destination. They offer clarity, stability, and direction throughout your journey.

I'll help you build 3.

What are you hoping to explore, heal, or understand? Share openly - we'll transform these together.
user0:
Look, I don't know how to do this. Heroic Hearts says I need these intention things for the ceremony, but I've never done anything like this before. 

I just need to stop waking up screaming. Amanda can't keep living like this, and neither can I.
system1:
Three threads:

1. Sleep through the night without screaming
2. Create peace for Amanda 
3. Find healing from what drives the nightmares

Let's turn these into intentions.
user1:
Yeah... those are the things. I just need to figure out how to say them right. 

I don't want to lose her. She's already walking on eggshells around me, and I hate that look in her eyes when I wake up yelling about things she doesn't understand. 

But I can't... I can't be one of those guys who falls apart. I need to fix this without becoming weak.
system2:
Based on those threads:

1. I sleep peacefully through the night
2. I make home safe for Amanda again
3. I face what haunts me without breaking

Which speaks strongest? Want to adjust the language?
user2:
The second one. That's the one that hits hardest - "I make home safe for Amanda again." 

Because that's what matters. My kids need to see their mom not flinching when I walk into the room. She used to laugh at my dumb jokes, you know? Now she just... waits. Like she's bracing for something.

I just need the words to be stronger. More... I don't know. Like a mission statement. Something I can hold onto when this plant stuff gets weird.
system3:
I make home safe for Amanda again.

How about: "I reclaim safety for my family" - stronger, mission-focused.

The other two:
1. I sleep peacefully through the night
3. I face what haunts me without breaking

How do these feel?
user3:
"I reclaim safety for my family" - yeah, that's better. That's what I do. I'm a protector, not... whatever I've become.

The other two... I don't know. "I sleep peacefully through the night" sounds too soft. Like something from a pillow commercial. And "I face what haunts me without breaking" - what if I do break? What if this stuff makes me fall apart in front of everybody?

I need something that doesn't make me sound weak before I even start.
system4:
Stronger versions:

1. I claim restful sleep through the night
2. I reclaim safety for my family
3. I confront what haunts me and stay standing

How do these land?
user4:
"I confront what haunts me and stay standing" - now that's something I can work with. That's a mission. That's what we do - we stay standing no matter what.

The sleep one still feels... I don't know. Maybe "I claim restful nights" instead? Shorter. More like taking territory than asking permission.

"I reclaim safety for my family" stays. That's the mission that matters most.
system5:
✓ All 3 locked in:

1. I claim restful nights
2. I reclaim safety for my family
3. I confront what haunts me and stay standing

Keep them in your wallet, morning routine, wherever you'll see them.

These are your compass. Trust what comes.

You're set.
user5:
Got it. I'll write them down. Keep them in my wallet - been carrying that thing for years through three deployments. Seems right to keep these close too.

Three weeks until Costa Rica. I can do this.
system6:
You can. Three weeks is time to prepare, not worry.

The medicine knows what to do with a soldier who's ready to fight for his family. Trust what comes.
user6:
I've been in tougher spots than this. Flew through anti-aircraft fire over Kandahar - I can handle some jungle tea.

Just... what if I see things I can't unsee? What if this stuff makes me remember things I've worked damn hard to bury?
system7:
The medicine shows you what you're ready to see, even when it doesn't feel that way.

What you've buried isn't gone - it's just waiting. Better to face it on your terms than have it ambush you at 3 AM again.

You've survived anti-aircraft fire. You can survive remembering.

Trust the process.
user7:
Better to face it on my terms. That's what we learned - take the fight to the enemy, don't wait for them to come to you.

Maybe that's what the nightmares are. My brain trying to ambush me because I'm too stubborn to look at this stuff head-on.

Alright. I'll trust it. But I'm keeping my eyes open.
system8:
That's the spirit - eyes open, moving forward.

The medicine works with warriors who show up ready. You've got the right approach.
user8: Thanks. I appreciate you helping me get this straight in my head. Three weeks. I'll be ready.
system9: You'll be ready. Safe travels, and trust what comes.
user9: Copy that. I'll bring everything I learned here with me.
user12:
Three weeks. Rythmia. Amanda thinks I’m going to some “wellness retreat.” I told her it’s for vets, which is true, and left it at that. She kissed me like she used to—hopeful—and I felt it in my chest, that old pull I’ve been missing.

I keep replaying what we worked out: face the dreams, save the marriage, stay strong. I wrote the words on a card, slipped it behind my driver’s license. Every time I open my wallet I see it. Reminds me why I’m doing this plant stuff I still don’t believe in.

Night before last the rotor-wash dream came back—sand, smell of fuel, somebody yelling “Angel-One, angels one-six.” I woke up swinging, knocked the lamp off the nightstand. Amanda didn’t even flinch, just rolled over and pretended to sleep. That’s when I knew I can’t screw this up.
system13:
Three threads:

1. Face the nightmares head-on instead of waiting for the ambush
2. Save your marriage by being the man Amanda kissed
3. Stay strong through whatever the medicine shows you

Let's turn these into intentions.
user13:
Yeah. Let’s lock these in.

1. When the dream hits, I meet it—no more swinging in the dark. I’ll breathe, name what I see, let it pass through instead of bottling it up for the next ambush.

2. I show Amanda the man she kissed—steady eyes, open hands, no more snapping when the noise in my head gets loud. I’ll ask her how her day went and actually listen.

3. Whatever the medicine throws at me—screams, flames, guilt—I stay on my feet. I keep my word to myself, to her, to the kids. I come back stronger, not softer.
system14:
✓ All 3 locked in:

1. I meet the dream—breathe, name it, let it pass through
2. I show Amanda the steady man she kissed
3. Whatever the medicine throws, I stay on my feet and keep my word

Keep the card where it is. Read it each morning with your coffee.

These are your compass. Trust what comes. You're set.
user14: Copy. Card stays. Compass set. I’ll see it through.
system15: See it through. Come back different.
user15: Different, not weaker. I’ll bring it home.
